Name: Forms
Description:
Forms is a two-players strategy game played on a square board. Initially half of the board is filled with black stones and another half of the board is filled with white stones.

A player wins if all his stones are removed from the board.

Players move alternatively by replacing any opponent's stone with an own stone taken from the board. After doing it a player removes all stones that aren't connected to the moved player's stone.

Name: Country Club Golf
Description: The object of the game is to play a round of golf in an attempt to par the course, just as you would on any golf course around the world. The game is designed to bring to some degree, the same enjoyment received in actual play. Since luck and skill are a part of each round played at your favorite golf course, luck and skill (in rolling the dice) await you as you enter the Country Club course, with its water and sand hazards.

Name: Imhotep
Description:
From the Sagacity Website:
"In the old kingdom of ancient Egypt, the pharaoh Zoser, convinced of his divinity, asked his chief architect Imhotep to design a grand tomb to house him in his afterlife. This tomb was to become known as the "stepped pyramid", the first of the great pyramids of Egypt.

Each player is a builder vying to add to their wealth through this grand project. The builders secure the services of some of the kingdom's artisans to supply finished stone for the pyramid and food for their workers. They then use these tiles to build the pyramid and are rewarded for their efforts by the treasury.

But building the pyramid is not the only way to gain wealth. There is a thriving market for the stone and food required to build the pyramid. There are profits to be made by selling goods on the open market and at times, tiles purchased on the market may let you build when you would not otherwise be able to do so. By deploying influential members of your family, you can also gain advantage in various aspects of your business dealings.

Use your money and influence wisely and the completion of the pyramid will see you take your rightful place as the kingdom's most successful builder."

Name: Kingdoms
Description:
Kingdoms is a card game which simulates two kingdoms or nations at war. It uses a tarot deck. The goal of the game is to eliminate all of the opposing side's cards/forces.

Full Game: http://www.gamecabinet.com/rules/Kingdoms.html

Name: Fantastical Factory Game
Description:
From the back of the box:

"Join Charlie and the other Golden Ticket winners on a fun-filled race through the Chocolate Factory!

All your fantastical favourites are here - the Chocolate Room, the Inventing Room, the Nut Room, along with the best of Mr. Willy Wonka's wonderful inventions, like Television Chocolate and the Great Gum Machine!

Each room is a game itself.  Dodge the traps and the various surprises te Oompa-Loompas and squirrels have waiting along the way and be the one who wins a ride with Mr. Willy Wonka in the Great Glass Elevator!"
Families: Books: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory

Name: Fraction Games
Description: This game comes with pieces of a circular pie in halves, quarters, thirds, eighths, and sixths.  The basic game is to complete a playing mat in as few rolls as possible.  There are 5 playing mats that show a full pie in each of the evenly distributed pie shapes (e.g. all 4 quarters).  The game is intended to be educational mostly.

Name: Sports Pursual
Description: A board game in which the object of the game is to gain the most money after 3 laps of the board are completed by dice throwing, questions and gambling of money in hand.

Name: Bajo el Sol de África
Description:
Spanish skirmish game for the period of the Africa exploration between 1830 (conquest of Argel by the French) and 1925 (end of the Rif war).
The rules not only allows for historical scenarios, but also to introduce more "fantastic" elements as Tarzan, Allan Quartemain etc, or set it into a more "steam-punk" Victorian setting.
The first edition is out-of-print but there is a 2nd one published in 2008

Name: Bajo el Sol de África: El Libro de los Ejércitos
Description:
Armies list for the Spanish skirmish game "Bajo el Sol de África".
It covers both the European nations (as regular armies and local-trained troops) and the African tribes and local warlords that waged during most of the XIX century in the Dark Continent.
Included Arae Anglo-Egypcians, Askari, colonial expeditions, Arabs and Swahilis, Azande, Majdist, Masais, Zulus,...

Expands:

    Bajo el Sol de Ãfrica

Name: Zoodyssey
Description:
From the box:

"Zoodyssey is the only family board game that combines the fun and excitement of going to the zoo with scientific understanding of some of the world's most endangered animals.

The game takes about 55 minutes.  Players move along the paths of the zoo and collect Animal Snapshot cards.  Each card has a picture of a zoo animal, some Fun Facts about that animal, and a point value.  The more endangered the animal, the higher the point value.

The object of the game is to be the first player with 50 points worth of Snapshot cards.

Of course it's never as easy as it sounds.  A rhino may stop you.  A toucan may steal one of your photos.  Or you may run out of film.  But nothing will stop you in your quest to add snapshots to your collection.

In the process, of course, you will come to a greater understanding of some of he magnificent creatures that share our planet.  And when it is over, you'll want to set-up and play again."

Name: Over They Go
Description:
A fun party game for all the family, Ages 4 and up
The object is to build a tower as high as possible before it topples and to score points accordingly.
There are two ways to play, rules for both are printed in the box lid.
The tower is built using the ping-pong type coloured balls and the connecting tubes.

Name: Derek Jameson's Headliners
Description:
Based on the classic TV show this is a fun board game for teams to play.
The players divide into 2 teams and compete playing as The Daily Mail or The Express.
Each team has a score pad divided into 4 decades and each decade is divided into 4 categories.  The object of the game is to tick off each box by the correct answering of relevant questions.
The first team to fill their card wins the game.

Name: Night of the Slasher
Description:
"Tonight the citizens of Hope County are being stalked by a merciless Slasher who will not stop until they have claimed enough victims to satisfy their sick thirst for death!

It seems that the Slasher is someone well known in the community... could it be the high school jock, the nurse, the convict, the geek or even the TV Anchorwoman?"

In this Print and Play game, each player takes on the identity of one of the 12 possible victims. One player will secretly play as the Slasher and has 8 rounds to kill all of the characters controlled by the other players.

The rest of the players must find clues to reveal the Slasher’s true identity or use weapons and other tricks to help them stay alive.

3 to 12 players can play this exciting game of strategy and suspense. Players will need to provide a 10 sided die.

This game has Adult Themes.

Night of the Slasher, the Print and Play game, can be purchased from  http://www.wargamedownloads.com/item.php?item=712&pics

Name: The Pursuit of von Spee
Description:
At the outbreak of the First World War the greatest concentration of German warships outside of the North Sea was the famed East Asiatic Squadron. Winner of the Kaiser's Cup for two consecutive years, a competition testing the gunnery of His Majesty's warships, the East Asiatic Squadron was commanded by Admiral Maximilian von Spee. The East Asiatic Squadron was made up of fast and modern ships. The flagship was the Scharnhorst, a fast armoured cruiser with 8.2" guns. Her sister-ship, the Gneisenau, boasted the same specifications. In addition to these two armoured cruisers, there were the light cruisers Leipzig, Nürnberg, and Emden, all very fast and armed with 4.1" guns. This fleet provided the greatest threat to Allied shipping outside of the north Atlantic.

Spee had several options when news of the war reached him. The greatest concentration of Allied merchant shipping in the region was at the approaches to the Red Sea, where convoys from India, China, and Australia passed through the Suez Canal. But there were no places for German ships to coal in the Indian Ocean, and operating there would bring Spee into contact with the Royal Navy China Station and the powerful but slow Triumph. Operating in the northern Pacific was ruled out because of the powerful Japanese fleet, easily the largest in the Pacific. Operating around the Dutch East Indies and Australia was also discarded because it would bring the East Asiatic Squadron within the sights of the Australia, a battlecruiser with 12" guns. With few options, Spee decided to head across the Pacific where he could indirectly disrupt Allied shipping and hopefully cause enough consternation within the Royal Navy that several important ships would be detached from the Home Fleet. The south Pacific had plenty of islands from which Spee and his ships could supply and the islands also provided an effective hiding place. With luck, Spee could reach South America and coal from neutral ports there, enter the Atlantic Ocean, feast on the rich merchant shipping around Montevideo, and maybe even reach Germany.

Not all commanders concurred and the captain of the Emden proposed that his vessel would head west into the Indian Ocean where a lone ship could more easily stay hidden and coal from captured merchants. Spee agreed and the Emden sailed west while the East Asiatic Squadron sailed east, where they were expected to meet the Dresden en route from the Atlantic.

What followed was one of the greatest war time adventures at sea.

Spee eluded capture for months and appeared off the coast of Chile where he destroyed a British fleet at the Battle of Coronel. Crossing into the Atlantic, Spee was finally sunk in December 1914 under the weight of the shells from the 12" guns of the Invincible and Inflexible, two battlecruisers dispatched from North Sea waters to deal with the German threat. The Emden had an incredible campaign of her own, sinking almost two dozen merchant ships and causing panic throughout the Indian Ocean. The Emden also met a tragic end at the hands of the Sydney in November 1914.

In The Pursuit of von Spee you are put at the helm of the German or Allied fleet. Your goal as the German commander is to disrupt Allied shipping, raid Allied possessions, sink Allied warships, and survive for as long as possible. As the Allies you are to capture the German colonies and seek out and destroy the German raiders all the while trying to keep your merchant shipping en route to their destinations and afloat.

The Pursuit of von Spee is a game of deception and subterfuge. One must keep in mind at all times that the winner of this game could very well be the best bluffer. Without knowing exactly where your opponent's ships are, a subtle look could give you the hint needed to find von Spee and send his fleet to the bottom.

The Pursuit of von Spee uses a fog-of-war system that hides the location and condition of the various ships in the game. Naval combat uses a system which takes into account the size of a ship's guns, its top speed, and the strength of its armour at various parts of the ship. The Allied player has a lot of responsibilities to take care of in addition to hunting the German player, while the German player has to choose his battles carefully and keep a close eye on the condition and coal-reserves of each of his ships. The German player also has the ability to bring two other ships into the campaign, the Karlsruhe and the Königsberg. The Allied player receives reinforcements as well during the course of the game.

In your game box you will receive four 12" x 18" map sheets which join together to make one 24" x 36" map spanning from the Indian Ocean to the Atlantic. The game includes 240 mounted counters (in easy-to-cut strips), one 10-sided die, two blinds, four ship charts, five player aid sheets, and a 17-page rulebook containing all of the rules and setup information required.

This game is of medium complexity but has only a few mechanics to master. Learning the game comes quickly as the phases are simple and straight-forward. In addition to regular playtesting, this game was also play tested with a first-time wargamer, who was nevertheless able to grasp the basics of the game in her first session. Learning the strategy and intricacies of play can take much longer, as the options in this game are endless. Depending on how long von Spee survives, the game can last anywhere from 2 to 12 hours.

Name: Shakeout
Description:
Denys Fisher had a reputation for producing some very 'different' games - not least Shakeout which involves each player taking hold of a plastic sphere filled with plastic sticks,  and having to shake it frantically to 'spill' out the contents.   These are then subsequently placed in various combinations upon a plastic scoreboard in a race to create the maximum points.  The first Player to empty his 'sphere' and score the most is the winner!

An unusual game, and one that is so simple it is consequently overlooked.

c1971

Name: Slink'em
Description:
A "3-in-1" board game to be played with a Slinky.

The games are played on a board that folds into a ramp. The players take turns sending the Slinky down the ramp trying to land on the best squares marked on the scoring field. All squares touched are added to the score. There game came with three different boards: "Numbers Game", "Baseball Game", and "Big Game Hunt."

The board for the Numbers Game has squares marked with positive and negative numbers. The center square is normally worth 10 points. However, if the Slinky ends up in "standing position" in the center square and not touching any other square, 50 points are scored.

The Baseball and Big Game Hunt boards are marked according to their themes.

The rules folder offers a bounty of $25 for anyone offering a suggestion for the improvement of the game that is accepted and used.

Name: Sexy Slang's Naughty Charades
Description:
This is the smaller "charades only" version of the adult party game Sexy Slang.  This version of Charades contains Sexy Slang terms.

The new game is marketed as the perfect inexpensive and unique gift for bachelorette parties and new brides.

The game is packaged in a small metal box and contains two card decks, 300 naughty charade terms, a naughty charades die, and a set of instructions.

Name: Pandarama
Description:
In this panda-themed game, players move along black and white squares of a game board, drawing cards with panda facts and movement directions.

This game was created by 9 year-old Amanda Wilcox along with twin sister Laura and their mother Melynda.  They started working on the game when Amanda was only about eight years old.  Proceeds of the game go to Washington DC's Smithsonian National Zoological Park Giant Panda Conservation Fund.

Name: The Road to Health
Description:
This educational game shows students the way to better health and physical fitness.  As players move their playing pieces around the board, they are asked questions to quiz them on six categories: safety, alcohol and other drug abuse, fitness, mental health and anger management, hygiene, and nutrition.

The game comes a 20-inch wide square board, game pieces, 120 question cards and (including 12 blank cards for adding new questions), and an instructor's guide that contains rules, variations, discussion starters, a die, and a set of reproducible worksheets utilizing all of the game's questions.

Name: Play Rethink
Description:
This drawing game with an ecological twist.  The players are to rethink existing, everyday products and attempt to make them more environmentally friendly.  For example, a player might attempt to redesign a piece of furniture using locally sourced materials or might attempt to come up with new functions for an old piece of equipment.

The game itself is also eco-friendly.  It is made in the United Kingdom using recycled and other special types of paper and vegetable-based inks along with eco-friendly laminates and other environmentally-friendly processes.

Name: Insel der Piraten
Description:
From the publisher's website:

Find the hidden treasure

Many hidden treasures wait on that secret pirate's isle. Luckily enough, the pirates have left you a treasure-map. But it is ripped in several pieces and no one knows the correct order. Each player can only look at one piece at a time. Try to find the correct location first!

Insel der Piraten - Pirate's Isle is more than a simple game of deduction. You have to draw logical conclusions to find the possible paths. Try to mark your guess first on the map and you'll be the winner. But be careful, other player can see where you're going. There are 20 adventures to solve. The game can be played with 2 to 4 player and even with a single player!

Name: Beat the Market
Description:
From the inside of the box (game description of the rules):

"This is a stock market game for 3 to 6 persons.  It is played with 4 loaded (8-sided) dice called Quotes which are designed to give the effect of a constantly changing market. The black Quotes are weighted so they usually come up with low numbers and the whole Quotes are weighted so they usually come up with high numbers.  Only 2 Quotes are used at a time so that a market can be low (both black), mixed (a black and a white), or high (both white).  Object if ge game is to buy stock at a low price, hold it for awhile, and sell it at a higher price.  The game ends when one player doubles his money or when someone goes broke.  Winner is the player who first doubles his money or the player with the most money when someone goes broke.  Each game lasts about an hour."

Name: Too many cooks
Description:
The game is really simple.
Each player has a plastic "fry-pan" and there is a central "stove".
The fry-pans are shaped as mazed and the stove has holes with points on them.

Players drop 1-3 balls on their fry-pans and by balancing the fry-pan aim to drop the balls on the higher value holes.

Name: Chameleon
Description: This is a game played on a Hex board wherein the winning condition is to form a line of either color connecting your two sides. You may play either color piece on your turn.

Name: Aztekz
Description:
From the publisher's website:

Free the lost souls!

Lots of lost souls wander around the old Aztec's pyramid. As a chief, you have to earn your right to rest in that pyramid. Free as many souls as you can to obtain your last sleep's place.

Each player has a chief and two slaves. The chief moves very slowly but can steal collected souls from other player's slaves. The slaves are fast and can collect souls to bring them to their chief. But the pyramid's maze is changing with every turn and your just-so-well-constructed escape-way is not blocked. Keep cool, because the more souls you deliver to your chief at once, the more score. But be warned: If you're too greedy, it may be over too fast and you'll end up with nothing.

Aztekz is a very complex collecting-game with very simple rules and a lot of strategic possibilities. Quick to learn, always tricky and challenging.

Name: Shellz
Description:
From the publisher's website:

The tricky quest for shiny seashells

Compete against other players in search for the most valuable seashells. Build a path that leads to the longest rows of shells to get massive points. Use your branches and curves, build over other cards to cut-off the others path. With the right card you can even dig-out other cards. Place your pawn wisely to get double score. If you manage to connect to paths together, you may even get the other player's score. With three cards on hand you can plan your path carefully, but still the other players may manipulate your path. Also take care not to concentrate on certain kinds of shells only, since the lower scored-shells also count at the end. The war goes off at the middle of the gameboard, it's getting crowded there! Will you stay cool?

Shellz is a tricky building-game. You sometimes have to "think around the corner". Don't let the beautiful shells distract you - it's a tough game for big brains.

For 2 to 4 players Ages 10 and up, 30 - 45 minutes playing time. English instructions included.

Name: Maternal Generations
Description:
(from the rulebook)     Maternal Generations is a quick 2 player card game of strategy.  Compete against an opponent to build up maternal "family lines" while considering the best moment to disprove your opposing lines.

Genealogy family lines are built as the player uses the research ability of cards in their hand to get cards from the "gene pool" on the table.  Then the player plays one card from their hand to their family line each turn, by placing a higher number card each turn.  When you are unable to play on existing family lines, they must start new ones, but only lines of 4 or more cards will score points.   Be careful to build lines that score enough points and are safe against the other player's disprove action.

The game contains 34 ancestor cards, 1 wild records search card, and a color illustrated manual.

Name: The Ancient Pirates of Pernia
Description:
Ancient Pirates of Pernia is a fantasy / strategy board game for ages 8 to adult that will provide hours of enjoyment!  It involves ancient weaponry prior to widespread gunpowder use.  Pirates will attack with ancient siege type weapons and swords to take cargo and plunder.

Game comes in a large "bag" and contains 8 sided Dice, and Directional Pirate Dice, Ship & Game Boards, Marker Clips for 1 to 4 players, & 50 Cards of; Action, Crew, Weapon and Cargo.

Name: Pilzsuchen
Description: A vintage children's race track game about searching for mushrooms. The instructions are in German. The game is played on a colorful gameboard with a fairy tale style fantasy painting of little people among a variety of mushrooms (both edible and poisonous varieties) that are growing in a forest. The game board has numbered points corresponding to the different mushrooms and characters on the game board. A set of cardboard markers are used in the game.

Name: Barons to Kings
Description:
Barons to Kings is a tile laying game where players build roads to gain movement and capture markets to earn needed funds.  Players build fleets and walls to protect their property while trying to avoid other players and the plague.  Battle takes place with cards and dice. 
 Each player picks a flag on one of the 4 corners of the game board.  This spot will be their starting point for every move they make.  Gold tile pieces represent various coinage of the age.   Gold tiles are the only way to buy new Military, Road & Wall pieces from the center pile which you will need to survive.  The only way to get more gold is to get a military unit to one of the Market Squares in the middle of the board & hold it.
Once your empire is built, you will expand towards the other players and begin to conquer.

Name: Americaopoly
Description: This version of Monopoly celebrates the United States of America.  Players compete to buy properties such as the Golden Gate Bridge, Route 66, the Statue of Liberty, the Grand Canyon, and Niagara Falls.  Land on the "Fourth of July" space to scoop up the cash from the center of the board.

Name: Boers
Description:
What would have happened if the Boers had won the war VS the British? How would it have changed history and the globe? In this game you can find out. This game expands into the future space exploration realm.
This game assumes they would have been similar to Nazi Germany, and maybe even helped them for awhile but would break off in the end as Germany won Europe, and Japan then would have won Asia and the Pacific and America would just hold them off so that they retained N. and S. America, but barely.

Name: Bombs Away
Description:
Bombs Away is a carrier game. You have carriers, battleships, cruisers, frigates, subs, bombers and fighters all to do battle against your opponent across an ocean map.
This was the designer's first game.

Name: Cattle Drive
Description: This is a card game about a cattle drive where you want to be the first player to get 1000 cattle to market per hand and 5000 per game. You have cards such as droughts, fires, water holes, wagons and more to prevent you opponent from getting his cattle to market, and to get more cattle of yours sold.

Name: Fire Away
Description:
Just a plain infantry war game with a few ships and airplanes....very simple. Using simple counters and a one page map, this game lets you play a quick game without many complicated rules.

Full Game: http://www.cruzan.info/pgames/pgames.html

Name: MAreenz
Description:
This is a mech warrior type game with 3 kinds of warriors and a number of enemy units to kill. You can have missions in this one to go grab stuff. This game is a free PnP game where you have your Mech Bots go out and try to get things against the enemy. Includes simple counters for the military, 4 hex maps and a template to create your own bots.

Full Game: http://www.cruzan.info/pgames/pgames.html

Name: Nova Glory
Description:
Nova Glory is a boardgame of starship fleet combat.  It uses a unique mechanic so the playing pieces do all the record keeping for you. Large fleet battles play quickly and the space map tiles allow for easy placement of various terrain features such as asteroids and planets.  There are four races in the game each with their own back story and distinctive play style.  Strategy cards simulate lucky shots or other special situations that add an element of surprise to the game.  The turn sequence keeps both players involved throughout the entire game.  Game includes several scenarios in addition to basic straight up fleet duels.  Rules are easy to moderate to learn.

Publishers website:www.NovaGlory.com

Name: La Bataille de la Bouteille, Champagne 1915
Description:
A wargame covering the French offensive in the Champagne during World War I, from February 16 to March 7, 1915.

Scale is one hex = 500 m, one turn = 2 days, units are regiments.

The French player moves first, then the German. Both players' turns are divided in phases: Movement/Entrenchment, Artillery, and Attack/Advance.

Eight pages of rules cover entrenching, zones of control, enfilade fire and artillery. The historical notes are another 11 pages, including a bibliography.

Name: Tempo
Description:
From the cover: "Get set! You're about to begin the fastest card game in the world"

The Dealer shuffles one pack of 55 cards and deals 11 face down to each player.
Player don't take turns in this games: everyone plays together and can make a move whenever they want.
The moves are:

1. Discarding a card: the cards you discard are spread out - face up
2. Drawing a card: you can choose any card on the table or you can take the first card of the pack.

Name: DICE Baseball
Description:
In DICE Baseball you get every player from every major league team who appeared in at least 18 at bats or 18 innings pitched.  Over 900 different players.  You can replay the entire 2008 season or just replay your favorite teams schedule.  You can even replay the 2008 World Series.  They are your players and you can do what you want with them.

DICE Baseball uses more than a dozen different formulas to calculate each hitter and pitcher. Players will perform just like they do on the field.  Each and every player is rated individually.

DICE Baseball will be available in November of 2008.  DICE Baseball uses two 10-sided dice to determine all of the play results. This gives you 100 different possibilities on every play.

Name: GEO
Description: GEO - An abstract strategy game where you place your 18 pieces on the board to make shapes to score points. Free download from http://www.printgames.net/english/detail_e/geo.htm

Name: Lex-O-Grams
Description:
Subtitled with: "5 Games of Words and Letters"

CONTENTS: The square 'box' that is ONE-inch deep by 7-inches along each side; 374 letters; and "Instructions" sheet.

The 5 Games, as detailed from the "Instructions", consist of the following:

"Anagrams": for 2 to 6 Players with the LETTERS face down, or unseen, when chosen from the pile and used to form 'words' of 3 or more from this. Before PLAY commences, then an agreed upon TOTAL of 'words' needed to Win is determined, and this continues until that amount were accomplished by someone.

"Letter Mix-up": for 2 or more players with all of the LETTERS shown face-up within easy reach for everyone during this, where an agreed upon number to form 'words' is determined before commencing PLAY, are selected by everyone, of which they must try to form a 'word' from those they've chosen. Play continues until ONLY (1) Player can form any 'word' from theirs, while the others are already having had to drop OUT from being unable to do this.

"Anagram Sentences": for 2 to 6 Players and based upon the previous "Anagrams" GAME, with forming sentences for this, and having the same 'Victory' conditions.

"The Game ADD or O-U-T": for 2 to 6 Players with the 1st Player having to select a 'word' of not less than 4 LETTERS while also NOT disclosing what that were, and ONLY placing the first LETTER beginning for their 'word' with what they've chosen. This goes on with the others putting theirs to make or add on to continue a 'word' until someone no longer can, and then they are forced out, with the LAST player remaining becoming the winner.

"Crossword Anagrams": for 2 to 6 Players with being very similar to "Scrabble" for the overall layout, while also for in this game, then all of the LETTERS are kept face-down when being selected from the pile. Everyone then chooses 15 LETTERS unseen to start off with, yet they can look at those in order to make some 'word' for placement, using portions of others already formed, or as for the entire 1st 'word' to begin the GAME with. Once they've done that, or conducted a "Discard", the Player has to "Draw" a single LETTER from either the face-up "Discard" pile (when that is created), or the others of the face-down ones, while PLAY continues until (1) Player uses all of theirs up.

Name: Hanga-Tanga
Description:
Here's a light strategy game that gives everyone a chance. These first rules require twenty-eight dice - fourteen in two different colors. I really like playing it with dice, but there's a variation described below that will easily allow players to play using as few as one die if necessary.

Also, you'll need an 8x8 checker board.

The object of Hanga-Tanga is to score the most points by arranging your dice in "lines". 
(from website)

Full Game: http://www.gamecabinet.com/rules/HangaTanga.html

Name: How Not To Be Seen
Description:
Players try not to be seen. They must occasionally risk being seen in order to obtain points, but risk certain death if they are seen.

Conflict is resolved by dice rolling. Players use cards of any type to represent their hidden people. It can be optionally played using poker chips. Dice can have any number of sides as long as each player has a matching set.

Based (very) loosely on the Monty Python sketch of the same name.

Name: Shootout
Description: The all American western family game. For 2 to 4 players Ages 6 and up. Comes with a beautiful full-color board, spinner, two decks of cards, two standees (gunfighter's women) and sixteen plastic gunfighter figures.

Name: Flinke Feger: Die magischen Pentagramme
Description:
Expansion to Wicked Witches Way distributed at Essen 2007.

Four pentagrams tokens are placed randomly on spaces numbered 9, 12, 15 and 18. If a witch arrives on one of these spaces, the pentagram token is turned up, and a special action takes effect.

Name: Da' Pres
Description:
Card Game about becoming president. Includes cards for every state. Has cards about different things you can do to become president, such as "Raise Taxes", "Decrease Welfare" , "Increase Defense Budget" , "Protect Natural Resources".
Full game: http://www.cruzan.info/pgames/pgames.html

Name: Warp Away
Description:
Just a plain Space Conquest Game. Simple counters show different ship types. Includes a 2 page space map.
Free from: http://www.cruzan.info/pgames/pgames.html

Name: Scooby-Doo! Board Game:  The Maze of Mayhem!
Description:
From Publisher: "Scooby and the gang are trapped in the creepy maze.  The keys to the old wooden door are buried deep so it's up to the gang to do some digging.  But watch out where you dig!  The last thing you need is a zombie on your trail!  Be the first to find the old key and escape the Maze of Mayhem . . . on a full belly of 'Scooby Snacks' of course!"

This is a basic roll-and-move game where players race to collect a key and three snacks before escaping from the maze.  The keys and snacks are all hidden throughout the board but among them are three different monsters from various Scooby-Doo episodes.  Once a monster is uncovered, it remains on the board and moves on a separate die roll each turn.  Monsters catch players and send them back to start, complicating the process of gathering keys and snacks and moving to the exit.  Because each player has the chance to move the monsters, there are typically many opportunities to slow down the progress of other players.

Name: Mini Volgrama
Description:
The game for the whole family based on the Spanish TV contest from the 60's. It is similar to Crosswords.

Content:

- 1 Board
- 1 Volgrama
- 6 patterns for letters
- 179 game pieces

Name: ATS Warfighting Guide #2
Description:
From the Publisher's website:

ATS Warfighting Guide #2 contains 52 pages of ATS material aimed at making the ATSer a system expert. Included in the new issue is George Anderson's ATS Robot, a card-based system for playing ANY ATS scenario solo with a random generation of actions by the 'enemy'.

The ATS Robot includes a set of over 50 cards (provided on cardstock for you to trim out) for use with George's solo rules.

Also included in the issue are the first installment of Drew Dorman's 'ATS Set Ups', suggested set up data for all six D-Day Ranger scenarios. You can set up either side Drew's way, then use the ATS Robot to hammer it out. Alone. Just like you like it! What's more, Drew uses the D-Day Rangers NEW Edition scenarios, which also happen to be included in the issue as a FREE bonus!

The FREE bonus approach continues...with a strip of funky new ATS leader counters bundled with EACH copy of ATS Warfighting Guide #2.

So this is it. And this is NO DRILL. The expert ATSer needs his warfighting, and he (or she) needs it now.

Name: Star Strike Vessel Compendium #3: Imperial Ships
Description:
This is an expansion for the board game Space Master: Star Strike and Space Master: The Role Playing Game. It includes stats for 25 different space vessels like fleet carriers, cruisers, destroyers, frigates, MMAC gunboats, TMAC fighters, SMAC fighters, survey/exploration vessels, transports, liners, freighters, scouts and orbital stations. Also included are 2 adventures for Space Master: The Role Playing Game, 11 mini-adventures for use with the included ships and 65 full-color counters.

This expansion was produced in 1989 by Iron Crown Enterprises.

Expands:

    Space Master: Star Strike

Name: Star Strike Vessel Compendium #2: Pursuit Class
Description:
This is an expansion for the board game Space Master: Star Strike and Space Master: The Role Playing Game. It includes stats for 32 different space vessels like MMACs, cutters, gunboats, TMACs, destroyers, cruisers, blockade runners and free traders. Also included are 3 optional pods for payload pallets, 2 adventures for Space Master: The Role Playing Game, 11 scenarios and mini-adventures for use with the included ships and 65 full-color counters.

This expansion was produced in 1989 by Iron Crown Enterprises.

Expands:

    Space Master: Star Strike

Name: Star Strike Vessel Compendium #1: Adventurer Class
Description:
This is an expansion for the board game Space Master: Star Strike and Space Master: The Role Playing Game. It includes stats for 29 different space vessels like survey/exploration vessels, freighters, shuttles, yachts, privateers, scouts, slavers, blockade runners and couriers. Also included are 2 adventures for Space Master: The Role Playing Game and 65 full-color counters.

This expansion was produced in 1989 by Iron Crown Enterprises.

Expands:

    Space Master: Star Strike

Name: Mythology: The Game
Description:
[From publisher's website:] Play the part of one of the mighty heroes of legend - Theseus, Perseus, Odysseus, Heracles, Jason, or Achilles - and work your way through the Labyrinth, battling opponents, slaying the fearsome Minotaur, and ultimately finding your way out of the maze. The Labyrinth rotates, so the challenges you face will change from game to game!

This is the fourth installment of Ology World games. The others include Dragonology : The Game, Wizardology : The Game, and Pirateology : The Game.
Families: Series: Ology board games (Templar Publishing / Candlewick Press)

Name: The Auction Game
Description: Players each receive 10 counters with which to buy cards. The card deck, which consists of 24 pairs of cards, each card representing half of an article, is dealt out evenly. Each of the 24 articles fits into a category of animal, vegetable, or mineral. To start, all players look at their cards and place (face down) any pairs they may already have. They then use their counters to buy cards that other players are auctioning. Players take turns being the auctioneer. At the end of the game you want to have the most pairs. If the number of pairs is tied, the tie is broken by the number of coins.

Name: Wrestle Wars: Adventures in the Squared Circle
Description:
The ultimate objective of a Wrestle Wars character is to win the Global Super-Heavyweight Championship Belt by beating his or her opponents in one-on-one competition.

Before you begin to play Wrestle Wars you will need the following items: paper, pencils, two or more ten sided dice (d10), and at least one other player. That's it. Now you're ready to create your very own Wrestle Wars wrestler and start playing. (from site)

You create your character by rolling dice for different attributes. You have five randomly determined Character Stats: Height, Weight, Speed, Build, and Crowd Appeal.

To fight, you have to spend your points to perform different maneuvers based on your class.

Name: Starts and Ends
Description:
Basically, the game consists of listing words related to a topic. Each word must either START or END in a key letter. Look at the graphic below to make this clear. You'll notice that every line has at least one shaded circle. A letter written in those shaded circles are the key letters for the word to be written in the next line. If a word passes through two shaded circles, then the player has a choice as to which letter he or she uses as the key letter for the next word.
(from website)

Full Game: http://www.gamecabinet.com/rules/StartsAndEnds.html

Name: Monopoly: Leeds (Limited Edition)
Description:
Only 500 copies of this private version of Monopoly were ever produced.

Note:  This is different than the public version from 2008.

Name: Monopoly: Leeds Edition
Description:
The legendary board game is finally coming home to Leeds where local firm Waddingtons first began making the game for the UK market in 1936.

Spaces are expected to include Millennium Square, Temple Newsam, Harewood House, Leeds Metropolitan University, the Victoria Quarter, the Royal Armouries, Town Hall, Civic Hall, Kirkgate Market, and Headingley Carnegie Stadium.  Thirty-three Leeds landmarks are to occupy the multi-coloured sites.

Note:  This game is different than the limited edition which was produced in 1989 with 500 total copies.

Name: Basic Tactics
Description:
Basic Tactics is a fast paced variation on the traditional card game of War, but with some strategic decisions. For 2 players.

You get: A one-page folded sheet with rules for the game on it, printed on parchment like paper.

You need: 1 standard deck of 52 cards (jokers optional) and a friend to play with.

Name: Capture
Description: Capture is a card game for 2 players. You must capture more cards than the other player by the end of one play through the deck. Play proceeds via 5 columns in a round. If you have the best scoring hand in a column, you get all the cards in it.

Name: Stacks
Description: Stacks is a card game for 2 to 4 players, played using a special deck of cards prepared from three other decks. Each player tries to build up stacks of cards of their own, like in solitaire. Whoever has the highest total wins.

Name: Target Practice
Description: Target Practice is a fast game of throwing cards at the other player's line to score points. It provides an interesting change of pace in an evening of heavy duty strategy games. For 2 players.

Name: Slyderz
Description: This is a cross between Checkers and Sorry. It should be real easy for little kids to play. Basically you have to eliminate all your opponents pieces off the board. Each Player has 12 pieces that he/she can maneuver across a 4 piece map/board. The pieces have different movement patterns (like chess).

Name: Paper Football League
Description:
This is part card game and part board game for football (American). Some real simple plays both offensive and defensive. A sample league provided. There are different cards included, both offensive and defensive cards. You play your cards to try to get the football to score.

Full Game Here: http://www.cruzan.info/pgames/pgames.html

Name: Fan Craze
Description:
An antique baseball game. The wooden board displays a simple baseball diamond with holes at each base where pegs could be inserted to represent the base runners. The board also has holes for tracking the number of balls, strikes, runs and outs in an inning. The scores for each inning are recorded by writing them on the score card. A set of forty-eight playing cards are marked with the results of an at bat, such as "single", "hit by batted ball", "wild pitch", "double play", "stolen base", "out on steal", "out on foul", etc.

The components consist of a cardboard box, instructions, wooden board, score card, and (per the instructions) forty-eight cards. In addition, this particular example of the game is marked on the box cover as the "pocket edition" compliments of Longman & Martinez Paint Makers, New York City.

Name: Rainbo
Description:
A simple 2 player game where pieces move and capture based on a colored dot on their face.

Each player has 18 pieces of their color (White or Black) to place in secret in any arrangement of their choosing within their starting area. Each piece has a colored dot in 1 of 6 colors (Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, Purple) and 1 of 3 sizes. Size and color of the dot determines rank, capturing ability and movement of each piece.

Play alternates between players and ends when one player has only one piece left on the board.

Name: The Victor
Description: A simple children's "spin and move" race game where the players seek to move their pieces from their start spaces to the end space, moving up the opposite sides of the board. The components include a game board and rules (both printed inside the bottom half of the box), a spinner, and a set of discs for each player.

Name: Life Savers Game
Description:
A game for two, four, or six players. The object of the game is for the players to use their life boats to rescue sailors from a wrecked ship and bring them to the beach. Avoid the hazardous "reef of rocks"!

The components consist of one "dial" (spinner), six differently colored counters (representing life boats), six differently colored discs (representing sailors.)

Name: Humpty Dumpty Sat On A Wall
Description:
A vintage, early twentieth century dexterity game. Each player has a small Humpty Dumpty figure which hangs from a suspended string. The players compete to maneuver their Humpty Dumpty onto a wall. Points are scored based on the facing and positioning of the Humpty Dumpty figure. For example, 20 points are scored for seating Humpty facing the player with both legs hanging over the side of the wall; but if only one leg is over the wall, the player scores 15 points. The winner is the first player to reach a predetermined number of points. An alternate race game is included where the players race to be the first to get their Humpty properly seated on the wall and detached from the string.

The components include the box, an instruction sheet, three Humpty Dumpty figures with string, three walls, and three clips used to attach the lines of string to the game table. The box and instructions state "British Manufacture. Made in England." No publisher is specified.

Name: SanQi
Description:
Players take turns to either add one of three colors of stone to the board or change the color of an existing stone to match its neighbors.

One player's goal is to create either a circle or a triangle of six stones of the same color.  The other's is to create either a straight line or a triangle of six stones of the same color.

Name: Photonic Attack
Description:
The players take turns to "fire" "photons" (pieces of their color) into a 7×7 grid from any edge.  A fired photon travels  in a straight line until it reaches the opposite edge or another photon: then it stops, and any adjacent photons change color to match it.

The winner is the player who has more photons of their color on the board when no more moves can be made.

Name: Boolean Rithmomachia
Description:
This game was inspired by the medieval game Rithmomachy. But whereas in traditional Rithmomachy the pieces are labeled with natural numbers and captures are based on arithmetic progressions and geometric ratios, in Boolean Rithmomachy the pieces have binary nybbles 0000, 0001, ..., 1111 and captures are based on the logical operations AND, OR, XOR, NOT.

For good measure, the board has also been updated from two dimensions to three.

Name: Monopoly: Somerset Edition
Description: This version of Monopoly is based upon the English area of Somerset.  Proposed landmark locations include St. Mary Magdalene Church and Wells Cathedral.

Name: EarthOpoly
Description:
Earthopoly is an eco-friendly version of Monopoly by Cinncinati-based game manufacturer Late for the Sky suggested Ages 8 and up
All the paper is recyclable. The ink is vegetable oil-based ink. The game pieces are either made by nature or completely recyclable, and many are made locally.  The outer wrapping is made from Earthfirst PLA film which is a bio-plastic.

The game uses carbon credits and clean air and recycling incentives to increase property values.  In the first printing, the tokens are to include the following: a lima bean, a piece of corn, a piece of crystal from Arkansas, a walnut pyramid, a bamboo ring, a shell, and an extravagant Botswana stone called a Carnelian.

Name: Fangs and Swords
Description:
From the Introduction:
" Battle rages on between orcs and knights. Green and yellow mix into a chaotic melee and no-one knows which side will win this battle. Each player attempts to make his side victorious, orcs or knights.

Mage towers scattered on the battlefield are strategic objectives, and it soon appears that who controls the most towers will reap the seeds of victory. "

Orcs and Knight fight on the battlefield in a chaotic melee.
Each player tries to secure small areas of the battlefield, hoping to regroup and turn the battle to his advantage.

Once an area of the battlefield is completely surrounded by orcs and knights, a tally is made on each flank to determine who controls that area.

Fight for control of 7 towers using tiles that have both Orcs and Humans in the corners.  Use your Power Tokens like Drummers, Leaders, Banners, and Shamans to increase your chances of victory on the field of battle.  The first player to control 3 towers wins the day.

Batt'l K'haos has well-written rules and is easy to pick up and learn.  It is on the lighter end of the game spectrum and plays in about 20 minutes.

Name: Course Cavalière
Description:
In this card and dice-free horse racing game, players place bets on the horses in the race based on their position in the final standings.  On a player's turn, the player chooses actions by placing cubes in the move zone or in the exploit zone.  Players seek to make the horses finish in the position secretly chosen. The race is in 12 segments.

Awards

     2008 - Les JournÃ©es Ludiques de QuÃ©bec - Public Prize

Name: Arkham Horror: The Black Goat of the Woods Expansion
Description:
A dangerous cult has risen in Arkham! Meeting in secret, these heretics and madmen consort with dark powers and offer up sacrifices to the Ancient One, while hordes of vicious monsters descend on the the town. It’s up to a small band of investigators to infiltrate the cult and learn from these dark rituals, yet even the most pure-hearted may find himself corrupted in the process. Will their efforts be enough to stop the Ancient One from awakening, or will the investigators succumb, one by one, to the blasphemous seduction of its Herald, the Black Goat of the Woods?

The Black Goat of the Woods is a small expansion for the Arkham Horror board game, and is a part of the Arkham Horror Series. This expansion features 88 new Mythos cards, 9 new monster markers, 1 Herald Sheet, and 76 new Investigator cards including new items, new spells, and the dangerous lure of corruption…
Families: Series: Arkham Horror Files (Fantasy Flight Games)

Name: Sour Grapes
Description:
Aim of the game:
To collect enough grapes (green tokens) to cover the card.

Each player has a card depicting grapes.
on each card there are 5 "sour grape" bad circles, only known to the owner.
Each player is given 12 tokens (grapes) to cover the 5 bad circles and 7 additional circles.

Player A takes one token from the player on his right and continue taken tokens from the other players until he takes a token which was placed in a bad "sour grape" circle. At this point the next player does the same operation, collecting tokens until s/he graps one that was a sour grape. 
The winner is the player who completes his/her card first.

Name: The Dance Game
Description: From the instructions:  The object of the game is to dance your way around the game board to receive a standing ovation.  The first two sides of the board relate to dance class, side three is the dress rehearsal experience and the fourth side actually has you on the stage performing.

Name: Bible Tik Tak Toe
Description:
Bible Tik Tak Toe

"Answer Bible questions, learn Bible facts, and enjoy Tik Tak Toe fun!"

Designed for 2 players or 2 teams, this religion game features 6 large illustrated tic-tac-toe boards and 12 easy to handle tiles. Includes a 64 page question/answer booklet.

Ages 8 - 12

(c)1994 Standard Publishing

28-02654

Name: The Outdoorsman Game
Description: Background from the instructions:  The OUTDOORSMAN GAME was created by avid sportsman in a sparsely populated, wildlife rich area of Eastern Oregon.  When he discovered that many of his junior high math students shared his enthusiasm for outdoor activities, he came up with a way to make statistics and probability more interesting to them.  Drawing on his own experiences afield and information from fish and game departments, he developed a game that would involve fishing and hunting while teaching certain mathematical concepts.  When people kept insisting that the game  was too much fun to confine to the classroom, the idea was born of developing an activity that would challenge and entertain sportsmen when time, weather, or resources prohibited an excursion afield.  The OUTDOORSMAN GAME is the result of those efforts.  In the game, the species of fish, fowl, and big game, and the seasons and areas in which they are pursued, closely follow the actual events as they occur in Eastern Oregon.  We trust you will find the OUTDOORSMAN GAME to an enjoyable and entertaining activity.

Name: Fotbollsspelet
Description:
Swedish trivia game with questions about football (soccer).

Before the game starts a referee is chosen. The referee reads the questions and keeps track of the score.

The questions come in 4 categories : Geography, Players, History and Misc. On a players turn a die is rolled to choose category:

1: Geography
2: Misc
3: Players
4: History
5: the Referee chooses a category
6: the player chooses a category

The first player to reach a certain score (agreed on before the game) is the winner.

Name: Pettersson und Findus: Auf Entdeckungstour
Description: Auf Entdeckungstour is a movement & memory game for children Ages 5 and up A player draws a hidden card with one of the 18 different images on the wooden board. The opponents try to lock up the correct image on the board while moving the Findus figure for a number of fields after each other. After a move, the card owner tells the next player the right direction to the correct image.

Name: Legends of Time and Space: The Dark Star Incident
Description:
From the publisher's website:
Two parsecs out from Void Station 57, the Abaddon/Sheol binary system spins through the stygian darkness. The twin planets would be lifeless ice-rocks if not for the Dark Star Containment facility for the criminally incorrigible.

The Terran Bureau of Investigation has traced a deadly new street drug to the facility. As contract investigators, you must resolve the situation as quickly as possible. However, your investigation only scratches the surface of a far greater menace.

---

The Dark Star Incident is a programmed adventure using Dark City Games Legends of Time and Space rule set. These rules provide game play very similar to that of Melee and Wizard from Metagaming.

Battles are fought with counters on a hex map that is included with the game.
Families: Series: Legends of Time and Space (Dark City Games)

Name: The Masquerade Game
Description:
"This new and pleasing game is composed of thirty-two cards, each representing a character in masquerade attire, and the whole forging such a collection as may be seen at the carnivals yearly held in Rome or Venice."

The winner is the first player to score thirty-two points. Publication date is approximate.

Name: The Reward of Merit
Description:
"The Reward of Merit; a new, moral, and entertaining game"

A race game in the spirit of Game of Goose. The game board has 37 illustrated spaces, each of which is marked with a rhyming moral. Examples include: "A Gardener; Plant what is good, root out what's bad; Then You'll become a charming Lad", "a Dunce; Return great Dunce, with marks of Shame; Unto the Place from whence you came", and "a Puppy; You're pert to all, yet nothing know; Therefore pay one, sweet-scented Beau."

At least one version of this game came in the form of a jigsaw puzzle, with the lithograph mounted on wooden pieces about 0.2 inches thick. The board was made up of 51 puzzle pieces, most of them representing a single space on the board, but with some pieces just filling in numbers on corners and others making up the centerpiece with the rules and final space. The completed puzzle board measured 18.25 inches by 15 inches.

Name: The Game of Kings
Description: An antique card game consisting of a deck of 38 cards, a sixteen page instruction booklet, and a red slipcase bearing a picture of King William II. The game is described as comprising "a brief history of the English monarchs, from the Conquest to the present time, with an engraved figure of each." The instruction booklet summarizes each monarch's reign.

Name: The New World Game of American History
Description:
"The New World: A game of American history from discovery to James K. Polk."

This antique card game consisted of a set of forty cards in a slipcase. Twenty of the cards depict famous people in American history with clues to their identity. The other twenty cards contain questions and answers about the original colonies and the first eleven presidents. The object of the game is to match corresponding cards from the two sets.

The game also includes an advertising card listing other games available from Josiah Adams.

Name: History of Philadelphia
Description: This antique card game contains sixty cards "with labels of five different shapes and four different colors." Each card gives information about a place in Philadelphia or person related to Philadelphia. Game play involved matching cards of the same place or person. This is a revised version of the game, following the first edition published in 1831.

Name: Running the Blockade
Description:
"Two or more players provide themselves with Wooden Pins. The object in view is to run between the lines of the blockading squadron and to reach Wilmington, N.C."

The game that appears to have been produced in the Civil War period. The game board is a maze that leads to a number of illustrated spaces on the board. Some of the spaces depict Civil War ships. These spaces require a player arriving on that space to pay stakes. Other spaces represent hazards such as a Shark, Torpedo, or Reef, which require the payment of a fine. The first player to reach Wilmington collects all the stakes and fines paid during the game.

Name: Commandments and Beatitudes
Description: An educational trivia card game from the twenties or thirties. Each card has two questions on it referencing a specific Commandment or Beatitude. Each card is also marked with a value in credits. There are four different play and study variations given. Depending on the game variation selected, the object is to either acquire the most cards or cards worth the most total credits.

Name: Wolf & Sheep Game
Description:
An antique children's trick taking card game.

"Farmer Brown was looking out a window of his barn and saw the wolves after his sheep. He loaded his gun and a race began. The wolves chased the sheep, and Farmer Brown, who was also a great hunter, chased the wolves."

"'Wolf' is a most fascinating children's card game. It is played with twenty cards by two, three or four players."

Name: Bible ABC's
Description: A card game from the twenties or thirties. Each card is marked at the top with a letter of the alphabet followed by a list of persons, places, and things from the Bible which start with the same letter. A Biblical quotation is also included on the cards. The rules specify twelve different games and game variations for use with the cards, including one game for younger children that can't read the cards well.

Name: Bible Books
Description: A card game from the twenties or thirties based on the books of the Bible, from the Old Testament through the New Testament. Each card describes a specific book and contains a number of questions about it. The rules specify seven different games to be played with the cards.

Name: Bible Cities
Description: Game 3 of the Profitable Play series from Judson.  A card game from the twenties or thirties. Consists of a custom deck of cards, each featuring a city from the Bible and  related Biblical quotations. Rules are given for four different games, including games designed for younger children and children who cannot read. In addition, there are five suggested methods for using the cards for study.

Name: High Crusade
Description:
High Crusade is a simple but challenging, set of fun science fiction wargames rules that are ideal for anyone looking to start wargaming using 15mm or 25mm SF figures or if you just want a quick simple game, that works.

High Crusade background is set in the Ion Age universe, designed by Alternative Armies, but they are flexible and simple enough to be tailored to any SF background.

They are now available on-line at; 
http://www.blease.pwp.blueyonder.co.uk/WG.highcrusade.html

Name: Toy Parade
Description:
"Toy Parade is a colorful, exciting game for pre-school kiddies, who need have no knowledge of numbers and counting; and an interesting game for older kiddies too."

A vintage "spin and move" children's game for 2, 3 or 4 young children. The spinner depicts toys that are also shown on the squares of the game board. After spinning the spinner, a player moves to the next square showing the toy that the spinner selected. There are also colored squares on the board which have special effects, such as causing backwards movement or the loss of a turn.

The winner is the first player to get all the way through the Toy Parade.

Name: The Great Galumphus
Description:
"The Great Galumphus, an amusing round game of cards."

An antique children's card game featuring a custom deck of cards marked only with colorful illustrations of fanciful animals and their unusual names. Some of these include the Painted Pooh Pooh, Puttyfaced Popcat, Hairless Hunkum, Long Eared Scootler, Spotted Snifflegrub, Lunar Lumpkin, Flying Umbratunk, and the Cissling Sand Snapper.

The design is credited to "Miss J. Veal" on the title card.
